document.docAuthor: Smolis, Adrian, Deharveng, Louis & Kaprus’, Ighor J.
document.docTitle: Endonura levantica Smolis, Deharveng & Kaprus’, 2011, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Studies on the non-European Endonura Cassagnau, 1979 (Collembola, Neanuridae, Neanurinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Studies on the non-European Endonura Cassagnau, 1979 (Collembola, Neanuridae, Neanurinae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Figs 1 –10
,
Tab. 1

Type material
. Holotype : adult female on slide: Israel : Nahal Keziv,
Quercus calliprinos
forest, litter, N slope,
16 .ii. 1999
, leg. T. Pavliček, ZIWU . Paratype : juvenile on slide, same data as holotype , MNHL .
Etymology. The species name refers to the historic name of the Near East.

Diagnosis. Habitus typical of the genus
Endonura
. Dorsal tubercles present and well developed, except tubercles Di on th.
I. 2
+ 2 dark-pigmented eyes. Buccal cone rather short. Head with chaetae A, B, C, D and E. Chaeta O present or absent. Tubercles Dl and (L+So) on head with 6 and 8 chaetae respectively. Tubercles De on th. II and III with 3 and 4 chaetae respectively. Tubercles L on abd. III and IV with 3 and 5–6 chaetae respectively. Abd. IV and V with 8 and 3 tubercles respectively. Claw without inner tooth. Tibiotarsi with chaetae B 4 and B 5 short.

Head. Buccal cone short. Labrum rounded, with ventral sclerifications as in
Fig. 4
. Labrum chaetotaxy 0?/ 2, 4 , prelabral chaetae not seen. Labium with four basal, three distal and four lateral chaetae, papillae x absent. Maxilla styliform (
Fig. 3
), mandible thin tridentate (
Fig. 2
). Chaetotaxy of antennae as in
Tab. 2
c and in
Fig. 6
. Apical vesicle distinct, trilobed. S–chaetae of ant.IV of medium length and moderately thickened, S 3 thinner than others (
Fig. 6
). Chaetotaxy of head as in
Tab. 1
a, b, and
Fig. 1
. Tubercles Cl and Af separate (
Fig. 1
). Chaeta O present or absent. Chaetae D and E free. Tubercle Dl with 6 chaetae, chaeta Dl 3 present (
Fig. 1
). Tubercle (L+So) with 8 chaetae, chaetae So 3 and L 3 absent (
Fig. 1
). Elementary tubercle BE absent. Chaeta A shorter than B.

Thorax, abdomen, legs. Body s-chaeta thin and smooth, distinctly shorter than nearby macrochaetae (
Figs 5, 8
). Chaetotaxy of th. and abd. as in
Tab. 1
d and in
Figs 5, 7–10
. Tubercles Di on th.I not differentiated. Chaetae De 3 on th. III and abd. I–III as minute microchaetae. Chaetae De 2 on th. II–III and De 3 on th. III connected with tubercle De. Chaetae De 3 on abd. I–III connected with tubercle De (
Fig. 8
). The line of chaetae De 1 –chaeta s perpendicular to the dorsomedian line on abd. I–IV. Tubercle L on abd. III and IV with 3 and 5–6 chaetae respectively (
Fig. 5
). Furca rudimentary with 7–8 microchaetae (
Fig. 7
).Tubercles Di on abd. V fused, with chaetae Di 2 as Mc and Di 3 as very small mi (
Fig. 9
). Chaetae L' and Vl on abd. V present. No cryptopygy. Chaetotaxy of legs as in
Tab. 1
d. Tibiotarsi with chaetae B 4 and B 5 short. Claw without inner tooth.

Discussion. In general appearance (shape of dorsal chaetae, chaetotaxy of central area of head and dorsal side of thorax and abdomen),
E . levantica
resembles two Spanish species, namely
E . gladiolifer (
Cassagnau, 1954
)
and
E . alavensis (
Pozo & Simón, 1981
)
. Differences beetwen
E . levantica
and the outlined taxa include the number of chaetae on head tubercle (L+So) (in
levantica
8 , in
gladiolifer
10 , in
alavensis
8–9 ), number of chaetae L on abd.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–10 .
Endonura levantica
sp. nov.
: 1, head, dorsal and lateral chaetotaxy; 2,mandible; 3, maxilla; 4, ventral sclerifications of labrum; 5, habitus and dorsal chaetotaxy; 6, dorsal chaetotaxy of ant. III–IV; 7, furca rudimentary; 8, tubercle De of abd. III; 9, tubercle (Di+Di) of abd. V; 10, chaeta Di1 of abd. V.

Jordana et al . 1997
).
